comments.commentBody:
The Fed has already lost credibility in my book by dithering. They may need to start taking fiddle lessons if this goes much further. As for those FB Governers who are still worried over inflation, just what are they on? Do they honestly believe it is a possibility, or they just willing to ruin the US economy for personal/political gain?

The real question is though, how to restructure the US job market? It may be too late to stop the off-shoring of basic manufacturing -- although it we don't sit well with large-scale dependence on foreign oil, how about the fact that nearly every single electronic device we use is now manufactured off-shore? And are we still giving companies tax-breaks for out-sourcing service jobs??

The census workers in New England may have gotten good vibes from the work and their fellow crew members, but I don't think that's universal.

I did a little enumerating here in Manhattan and found the experience mostly frustrating and disappointing. Due probably to a lack of planning and ineffective management.

My only blessing is that I'll never do it again -- in ten years, I'll be far too old and too cranky!
Just watch the fake employment figures plument.  Next the Government will hire millons of people to be teachers aides

The type of people profiled in this article used to constitute the middle class. They understood how post-War America worked, and could navigate their way through it. Now, there's no place for them in the economy. Maybe they could retrain, if there were something to retrain to. Green jobs? That means subsidies, and another cycle of borrowing and printing money we don't have, and can never pay back.

I think the problem is that it just costs too much to live as an American. Look at those Russian agents who were just deported. Despite, in many cases, landing respectable gigs, they needed to smuggle bag after bag of cash into the country in order to maintain their covers. These days, how can a worker live the American Dream without bankrupting any potential employer?

I think a lot of people just aren't looking hard enough for a job. I just looked on craigslist in each of these cities, and there are hundreds of jobs. If you think a degree means anything, it's time to get over yourself. I collected unemployment once in my life, and thought it was easy money, and that I could just be selective and wait for the "right" job to come along. I was only fooling myself.

I've lived in 7 different states, and have had over 20 jobs, so I know what it's like to start over. Several times, I've flown to a new city with $100.00 in my pocket, and had work by the next day. Have faith that things will work out. Don't let depression set in, it's very real and will hold you back from moving on. Go out to the coffeeshop and talk to everyone you see. I've gotten jobs this way, too. You never know who will walk in.

My job finding strategy is this: send a resume to every job opening, and go through the phone book page by page, calling every company, until you have a job. Do whatever it takes. Every job requires on the job training, you just need to show a willingness to learn. Take the first job that comes along, even if it sucks. From there, something better will come along. When I lived in Portland, I would wake up at 3:30am, walk to the Labor Ready site in the rain/snow, and wait for lousy day labor jobs to open up, that paid only $50.00 per day. I'm college educated and used to think I was special for that, but I wasn't above doing whatever it takes to pay the bills. I did this every day, while applying for every job I saw. Eventually, I got a steady job.

When I moved to Texas at the beginning of the recession, I had a job 9 hours after I landed. The job was hard work, and after 2.5 years, I quit that job and started my own business. I'm now making $125,000 per year.

The only thing that will pull us out of the recession is a change in attitude. God bless America.

These Census jobs only illustrated the Zen concept of the transient nature of life. These jobs were close to a figment of the employed (soon to be unemployed) workers' minds. The main benefit of these jobs was to help the Obama adminstration create the Wizard of Oz like facade that the economic recovery was under way with growth in jobs and reduction in unemployment. Now that illusion has evaporated.

For the people who spent time on the dead end jobs, they wasted time that might have been devoted to getting either training for real, long term jobs and careers, or for searching for real jobs with a future.

The only real jobs are going to be created again is through stimulus and encouragement of the private sector. The way to do that is not through more dead end government programs that produce temporary jobs but through reducing, rather than increasing, taxes on businesses and investors. Businesses will hire more people in response to more consumer and business demand. Across the board tax cuts have proven historically the most reliable and potent drivers of long term revitalization of consumer and business spending, investment, and increasing payrolls.

No, #1, your tax money wasn't "wasted" on census workers. The Constitution requires it and accuracy is important so that our congressional representation will be proper. Why isn't that important to you? I can't imagine what "functions" you're talking about where you had to "endure" the census "hype." Why did you go to those functions? Or just leave? I know, I know, Obama is president, a census had to be done, so by extension of your irrational hatred of Obama the census was bad and wrong. Got it.

This is precisely the kind of forced spending and false stimulus that Krugman keeps yammering about.

Eleven billion dollars later - do you really think we now know anything more about who lives where in this country than we would have, had we collated across the 5-6 largest mailing lists in the hands of credit card and Internet-based companies?

It's the same kind of thinking that goes into all of these ostensibly hyper-accurate and hyper-fair electronic voting machines - so between twenty and sixty percent of us can vote, in any particular election.

Let me just drive the point home. Something we could get for free with electronic voting is the ordering of the parties. That is, for each voter, the rows would be presented randomly, so - on the average - no party had an advantage, simply because they occupied the electoral equal of the pole position.

Silence.

That's what I thought.

700,000 census jobs! Is that part of Obama's "jobs created or saved" ? Now they're gone. Can any Democrat understand that government jobs do NOTHING to grow our economy out of this recession. Now the Dems  want to raise taxes on small business owners and investors who take the risks to build the private sector economy and create REAL jobs for America's middle class. Bigger government isn't the answer; private sector initiative is!!

I worked as an enumerator, but was one of the lucky few who was actually able to quit after receiving a full-time job offer in late May. I suspect this is largely because I'm a young, recent college graduate. But, as this article describes, most of my coworkers were middle-aged, a lot of them appeared to have been laid off. While there were a few who seemed like they were former 'white collar' professionals, most talked of past admin/secretarial work. There were also quite a few who seemed to be perpetually unemployed, extending to before the Census.

The job was a savior for me financially, but if I had ever been in a high tax bracket I would have been horrified to witness the massive bureaucratic waste my tax dollars were funding. About 25% of the inefficiency was caused by employee incompetence (I shudder to imagine what previous Censuses were like), with the remaining 75% being produced by the needlessly repetitive paperwork/bureaucratic b.s. required by the federal government. The Census effectively creates an army of redundant functionaries every 10 years.

I have been working on Census 2010 and have found the people I've worked with to be much like those described in the article. Most all were enthusiastic and hardworking, and performed their jobs well.

As to the expense of the census, if 100% of the forms had been mailed in as opposed to the 72% that were, billions of dollars could have been saved. The Census is mandated by the Constitution and must be carried out, and the most economical way to do that is with a well informed populace paticipating in a timely fashion.

As Krugman has said we are in the start of a DEPRESSION. He is a LIBERAL! With Bush's tax cuts expiring in 2011. We need JOBS. The only way things can improve   I read from an economist by the name of Laffer recommended that we have a MORATORIUM on paying taxes for 18 months. That would include payroll taxes, sales taxes, real estate taxes ETC. This  would cost a lot (about 2 TRIL) but it would be money well spent. It would create jobs,have SMALL BUSINESS expand , and have consumers spend. He said the unemployment would go down to 5% which would be FULL EMPLOYMENT! It's worth a try.
Good Job Mr. President! 2nd term well earned.

So what.
TARP and the "stimulus" were just Dems' pet project smoke and mirrors as well.
Time to dig in and affect real economic drivers so that real companies make real hires and real investments.

Why don't we just hold the census every year?

Problem solved!

Perhaps we can employ some of these people to blog/twitter about the progress china is making in technologies such as alternative energy. Meanwhile our 'best and brightest' are patiently waiting to collect the scraps from financial commissions off of real progress.

I'm looking, too (laid off from Microsoft in Nov.) and I wrote a book to help: "How to Make Money While You Look for a Job." I made the e-book (120 pages) available free at 7StepsToMoney.com. I am earning income writing tech docs and articles for a local paper, and reporting it to the employment commission, of course. I share my path to success and I'd like to hear your struggles. I blog at OneAmericanWriter.com. See you there, and God speed you on your path to success!!
Why is the need for exact number? It changes the right next day because birth and death are going on all the time.

I don't get this story. Temporary workers were hired. They were paid way above market in terms of labor supply and demand...great for them, but taxpayers paid the premium. Now their temporary job is over. What is the story here except that the economy isn't recovering?

When will the NY Times finally write the story about how our president promised to turn his full attention to employment and then did everything but.
An accurate census is important.

What a scam the un-employment figures are, they only count the people who COLLECT un=employment.
I have been un-employed for two years along with thousands if not millions of self-empolyed un-employed. The media does not want to know about what percentage this represents.
The current REAL un-employment figures, they are about 28% nation wide.

they had better pass the unemployment bill asap or this country will see a real recession more foreclosures, no spending at all because the people will have no jobs no money. so every one better get ready. my husband has been layed off for a year, no construction, and no one loaning money to build commerical buildings. so the tv makes it sound everything is ok , but it is not. and we keep sending jobs overseas. our goverment better wake up . we need some people in our government with some common sense.

good luck everyone, i feel really bad for the american people

texas lady

How about the BILLIONS $ spent to create or save less than 100,000 jobs so far. JobsPush.org costs ZERO $ and has millions of jobs to fill. The second question is why they're not being filled? Who got rich from these stimulus $?

I am one of those census workers who came out of forced retirement a few months ago and have enjoyed the whole experience. It has made me want to go back into the work force when this is over in another month.

This job is not for the faint of heart! I have been chased by dogs, walked down dirt roads to cabins in the woods, entered a lot of dark hallways apartments run by slumlords along with trying to find out who lived in burned out crack houses on April 1st! Yes, it is a challenge and I alone have found hundreds of people that would have never been counted! In New York State alone one person equals $1,500 per year for state/local/national monies.......thats $15,000 in ten years. I would say the average census worker is really underpaid!

My pay for 10 weeks: $3,800

What I uncovered for my local/state/national payout for my work:

700+ persons $ 1,050,000 per year

$15,750,000 payout till next census

I would say the US Taxpayer is getting a good return on this census worker!!!!

It may mean a menial job to some folks, but to those who had those jobs of census workers, with meager wages, it meant a lot. Shame on America, for looking down its nose as other Americans scrounge for any means to live. Double shame on those Obstructionist Republicans, in our Senate, and one or two Democrats, who pull political stunts, like mouthing platitudes about controlling the deficit on the backs of the unemployed and their families. As these hypocrites went home and celebrated the 4th of July, while making life more miserable for those unemployed, because their unemployment benefits were not extended !! When are we bringing back, debtor's prison !!?
